Show HN: Algorithmic Trading for Everyone
text:
Hi everyone.

Hope you are all doing well.

I developed a company that offers a playing field for financial advisors and investors.

The playing field consists of a website where investors can connect their brokerage accounts to trading strategies developed by financial advisors.

Developers can either:

  - Create algorithms and post trading signals in exchange for a fee

  - Create financial data resources for other users to use in exchange for a fee
Investors can combine multiple trading strategies to manage their portfolios. They can also subscribe to multiple real time financial data resources that could help with their financial advisory decisions.

The interaction with the platform can either take place manually through the website or automatically through an API ( https://justfor.fund/api_documentation).

Next steps on the development of the company:

  - Focus on retail investors' experience and involvement.
  
  - Implement seamless brokerage account creation depending on the region where the user is based.
  
  - Integrate other brokers to the platform (Ameritrade TD, Robinhood, Interactive Brokers, and more).
  
  - Make payment settlements within the platform more efficient and cheaper. (Currently using Paypal but I want to implement Payoneer and Stripe).
  
  - Raise capital for covering costs.
Any feedback, help or advice is very much welcomed.

Thank you for your time.

Sincerely, Mat√≠as Mingo Founder and CEO at JustForFund Spa. Email: justforfundtrading@gmail.com Santiago, Chile.

Ps: Currently looking for a job as a developer or as a contractor.

Ask HN: Is it possible for someone like me to transition into management job?
text:
In my last two jobs I was made "leader" with the promise of transitioning to management. Yes, I know.

The problem is that I'm never really given "real authority" or real support in the meantime. Someone told me this is called a "poison chalice", that I wasn't really an authority and shouldn't have taken on a "promise". Two times I got ambitious/difficult employees ignore me and try give orders to juniors, boycott me and go direct to my superior for everything. While I do have a great relationship and I'm treated as a manager by the rest of the team, I understand why someone wouldn't respect me: I'm not a real manager!

However, others have said that a more capable person would be able to navigate this easily and "go get" management. That the guy able to command while I wasn't there was actually the "real leader".

I'm a quiet guy who avoids confrontation. I never got feedback from management, but a management course teacher told me I'm not direct enough. However attempting directness to those problem employees always led to a lot of drama, which ended up looking bad on me.

Is there anything I can do? Is this normal, and I'm just giving up too soon? Should I stop trying and just continue being an individual contributor? Is there any path to real management for someone who's not a "natural born leader"?

title: Ask HN: Why are all companies using hiring websites
text:
